title: 103_s1899
content:
SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Augusta Canal National Landmark in Georgia is listed on the National Historic Register and designated as a significant resource. It boasts excellent water quality, historic landscapes, and recreational opportunities. The area connects several national historic districts and landmarks, offering scenic vistas and undeveloped spaces for visitors. The Augusta Canal and related mill sites represent the development of the cotton textile industry in the South. The area has significant sites related to various historical events and communities. Despite efforts by the State of Georgia, the area's resources have not reached their full potential and may be lost without federal assistance. The Secretary of the Interior considers this landmark important. The Augusta Canal National Historic Landmark is considered threatened and a priority for protection by the Secretary of the Interior. Local, regional, and State agencies, businesses, and private citizens are eager to work together to preserve and enhance the resources of the landmark. The purpose of this Act is to provide a cooperative management framework to assist in retaining, enhancing, and interpreting the significant features of the Augusta Canal. It aims to have a positive economic impact and development for the benefit of present and future generations in Georgia and the United States. The Act establishes the boundaries of the Augusta Canal National Heritage Area. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT AND BOUNDARIES OF AUGUSTA CANAL NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA.

(a) Establishment.--The Augusta Canal National Heritage Area is established in Georgia.
(b) Boundaries.--The Heritage Area includes lands in Georgia and South Carolina known as the Augusta Canal, as depicted in the Augusta Canal Master Plan. The Secretary of the Interior will publish a detailed map of the boundaries.

SEC. 4. AUGUSTA CANAL COMMISSION. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed from various entities. The Commission will elect a chairman from its members, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Augusta Canal Commission is required to prepare a management plan for the Heritage Area within a year of this Act's enactment. The plan must integrate existing Federal, State, and local plans, including the Augusta Canal Master Plan, to protect and enhance the area's cultural, natural, scenic, and recreational resources. The Secretary can offer technical and financial assistance for plan preparation, and must approve or disapprove the plan within 180 days of submission. The Augusta Canal Commission must prepare a management plan for the Heritage Area, considering factors like local support, economic activity, partnership potential, and property rights. If the plan is disapproved, the Secretary must provide reasons and recommendations for revision. The Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the management plan to the Secretary for approval within 180 days. Upon approval, the Secretary will work with the Commission to implement the plan through cooperative agreements with various entities for economic development. The Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the management plan to the Secretary for approval within 180 days. Economic development in the area should be encouraged by the Augusta Commission, the State of Georgia, and other entities in line with the Augusta Canal Master Plan goals. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS. This Act does not impose stricter regulations on the Heritage Area than those in place before its establishment. No Federal agency can introduce more stringent regulations solely due to the Heritage Area's creation. SEC. 7. DUTIES OF OTHER FEDERAL ENTITIES. SEC. 7. Duties of other Federal entities include consulting, cooperating, and coordinating activities with the Secretary and Augusta Canal Commission to ensure no adverse effects on the Heritage Area. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out this Act.
